Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8844919354:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n

\nHow To Quickly Clean Up Disorganized Web Content\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n7/8/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n
\n

If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the prospect of cleaning up your website content, the suggestion to “get an overview of your content” may sound glib and unhelpful, but it really doesn’t need to be more complicated than that.

\n
\n

There are plenty of tools available to assist you in putting together an overview, so there’s no reason to ever waste your time manually creating a website inventory.

\n\n

Free tools may require a bit more manual effort, whereas paid tools offer greater speed and ease of use. Whatever your budget is, any tool will be much faster and more accurate than having a student worker copy and paste page titles into a spreadsheet.

\n

When evaluating whether free or paid tools are best for your organization, consider which of the basic three project ingredients are most important to you: speed, quality, and price. 

\n

\n

In order to get an overview you can actually use, make sure your tool(s) at least provide a complete list of:

\n
    \n
  • A full XML Sitemap
    • \n
  • Hosted documents (PDFs, Word, Excel, etc.)
    • \n
  • Contact information (email addresses, phone numbers, etc.)
    • \n
  • Broken links
    • \n
  • Misspellings
    • \n
  • Pages ordered by popularity (number of page views)
    • \n
\n

Once you have your content overview, you’re ready to begin cleaning.

\n

Step 1: Fix website errors

\n

Fixing all the errors that affect key pages is the single fastest way to make a noticeable improvement to the usability of your website. Broken links are more than just detrimental to your search engine rankings; they’re a virtual roadblock to your users and potential customers when they try to locate information on your site. Most visitors head straight to their favorite search engine after hitting a broken link, never to return.

\n

Misspellings are similarly disastrous to your user experience, destroying your organization’s credibility and reducing conversions by up to 50%. Fixing these issues is a simple and straightforward task that will dramatically increase your web content quality and give you a quick win.  

\n

Step 2: Remove unused content

\n

With Google Analytics

\n

Log in to your website’s analytics tool and sort your pages by page views over the past year.

\n

On your dashboard menu, click “Behavior,” then “Site Content,” then “All Pages.” Then click the “Pageviews” column header to sort by number of page views. 

\n

\n

 

\n

You may notice many pages that have titles beginning with a question mark followed by lots of seemingly random characters. This is tracking information, and often not an accurate representation of how many views the page in question has actually had. Skip those for now.

\n

Google Analytics is limited to displaying pages that have had at least one page view during the time period you select, so pages with zero views will not appear in this list.

\n

With Siteimprove

\n

If you’re a Siteimprove customer, you can view your least viewed pages under the “Inventory” section by clicking the “Pages” option. There you’ll see a list of pages with the least views, how many pages link to them on your site, the date they were added, a calculation of the page quality, number of views and page level on your site. 

\n

\n

 

\n

Step 3: Refresh outdated content

\n

Now that you’ve slimmed down the number of pages on your website, you’re ready to update the remaining content. This may require a bit more thought and planning than fixing errors or deleting unused pages, so you’ll feel better if you do it after you’ve already enjoyed some progress.

\n

Start by searching for expired contact information:

\n
    \n
  • Names of employees who have left your organization
    • \n
  • Phone numbers
    • \n
  • Email addresses
    • \n
  • Mailing addresses
    • \n
\n

If possible, log in to your CMS and sort your pages by last update. Many CMSs offer this functionality, but if yours doesn’t, use your website’s search bar to check for signs of outdated content:

\n\n
    \n
  • “2010/2011/2012”
    • \n
  • Names of events, projects or initiatives which may no longer be valid
    • \n
  • Old slogans or terminology
    • \n
\n

\n

Next, check your hosted documents, as these are commonly forgotten when updating information on the website. Make sure the information is up to date, and convert any platform-specific documents (e.g. Microsoft Word files) to PDFs so that they can be opened on any device.

\n

Step 4: Create a long-term solution

\n

Fixing all the issues on your site is only a short-term solution. Those issues are symptoms of a much larger issue, which is a lack of structure and definition in website marketing efforts. If you don’t fix the root problem, your website will quickly go back to being disorganized and confusing.

\n

Fortunately, the long-term solution is readily available and completely free: web governance. By creating web governance for your organization, you can effectively prevent your website from returning to its previous state of disrepair.

\n

Learn how to manage your web content and organize your team in this free on-demand webinar1

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8957699154:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Accessibility and the Law\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWeb Accessibility and the Law\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n

Time & Resources

\n

For some organizations, they don’t have the time, resources, or technical knowledge required to make their website functionally usable to those with disabilities. Instead, they aim to meet the minimum requirements, which may protect them from legal or regulatory issues, but will prevent users with varying disabilities from interacting with the site in a reasonable way.

\n

For other organizations, they are either willfully or blissfully unaware of the issues that can arise from having a website that doesn’t meet web accessibility standards.

\n

Legal Action

\n

The legal implications can be serious. A parent recently sued the Seattle Public School District because she is no longer able to access the school district resources needed to help her children with their schoolwork. She claims that the school district’s new website developer made changes that were no longer compatible with her JAWS Screen Reader, a common device that allows the visually impaired to have on-screen text translated into audio. 

\n

Resources

\n

These situations are easy for organizations of all shapes and sizes to avoid, and we have a library of knowledge resources available to help ensure that your website provides the best experience possible for all users.

\n

On-Demand Webinars:

\n

Introduction to Web Accessibility

\n

Cognitive Disabilities & Web Accessibility

\n

Why Semantic Markup Matters for Web Accessibility

\n

eBooks:

\n

How to Create Accessible PDFs

\n

For more helpful information about Web Accessibility.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Vichaya Kiatying-Angsulee at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\nLogin\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

A reliable 24/7 monitoring and reporting service

\n

When you are responsible for the success of your organization’s website nothing is more discouraging than being the last to hear about website issues such as crashes, slow response times, and irregular behavior. Siteimprove Response provides real-time alerts of website issues, anytime, anywhere – enabling you to fix problems immediately.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

But what if the Siteimprove system goes down?

\n

Being a leading SaaS company, we are experts at ensuring that our system can withstand heavy tasks, and ensuring our system never lets you down is an integral promise we stand by. Systems in place ensure that even if one of our servers were to go down, which is highly improbable, our various backup services across the globe would be on hand to keep you protected.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    How does it work?

    \n

    Siteimprove automatically checks your website(s) domain URL and/or multiple URLs 24/7, monitoring response time and alerting you of any downtime. Checks are monitored from a series of reliable servers across the globe.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Monitor and check URL response times

    \n

    Using Siteimprove Response Checkpoints allows you to easily setup an unlimited amount of URLs for response time monitoring. Each Checkpoint displays a clear summary of statistics indicating current up-time, response time, instances and causes of downtime, as well as historical data and useful configuration settings so you can simply oversee website performance.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Get immediate website downtime alerts

    \n

    Siteimprove Response ensures content integrity is well guarded around the clock, and if serious performance issues do arise on URL Checkpoints then you and unlimited users are notified immediately by email and SMS. This allows you to react instantly and minimize content integrity issues or downtime affecting your website and users.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Pause URL checks during maintenance

    \n

    If you know your site or specific content is down for backup or maintenance at specific periods of time, you can create URL Check Pauses, in which Siteimprove Response will not perform checks. This can be extremely useful for ensuring consistent role and responsibility management during website relaunch projects, devolved content and websites with multiple content editors.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Receive automated Response reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Response automated Reports are delivered directly to your inbox daily, weekly or/and monthly. The Reports clearly display an overview of your website’s up-time and response time performance with clear graphics and historical data throughout a given time period.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove Customer Experience

\n

Online support services - Access product information, software updates and technical support resources online within the tool.

\n

Expert technical assistance - Siteimprove’s trained Customer Experience team is available to provide free expert advice and assistance for all your training and support needs.

\n

Full upgrade protection - Software upgrades and documentation are free, ensuring you stay current on the latest technical developments.

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9131523304:\n\n\n\n\n\n4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n

\n4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n

Let’s look at some of the ways you can get your website back into shape.

\n

Clean up broken links & misspellings

\n

The problem:

\n

The reasoning behind this should be pretty obvious, but for far too many organizations, broken links and misspellings have a tendency to build up over time like the aforementioned desk clutter. Like the quirky comfort provided by your messy desk, it can be easy to overlook the affect that your messy website has on others because you see it every day. Unfortunately, when customers who aren’t as familiar with the intricacies of your website’s poor grammar and labyrinth of dead links see it for the first time, it can be a major turn off that hurts your organization’s reputation and could result in lost revenue.

\n

The solution:

\n

Take the time to analyze your most important pages- the ones which see the most traffic and/or drive customers through the conversion process. Correcting misspelled words and fixing broken links on these crucial pages will result in quick, large-scale improvements to the user experience of your website.

\n

Set a goal for your team and determine a timeline for when you want to complete it. For some organizations, it may not be possible to scan every webpage and address every error, and that’s OK. The important thing is make a measurable improvement that will benefit both you and your organization.

\n

Optimize your site architecture and navigation

\n

The problem:

\n

This may come as a surprise to some of you, but the content that you think is the most important to your customers may not be what the customers think is the most important for the customer. That can be a hard pill to swallow when you’ve spent what seems like a large portion of your sanity on laying out your website in a way feels logical, or that you think will allow you to reach your business goals.

\n

Unfortunately, that’s not the way it works. In this case, the customer is always right. They’re going to find what they need, with or with your help, so it’s in your best interest to help them.

\n

The solution:

\n

Data doesn’t lie, check your analytics. Your analytics data will show you the journey that every customer is taking and reveal why they’re coming to your website. Use this information to determine what’s working and what’s not working. What pages are receiving higher or lower than expected traffic and engagement? Where are customers entering and leaving your site? What page elements are they clicking on? All of these metrics will help you decide which pages should be moved higher or lower in the pecking order.

\n

By adjusting your website’s layout to reflect your customers’ needs, you enable them to find what they’re looking for with the least amount of resistance, resulting in more engagement and more business for you, and more warm-fuzzy feelings for the customer.

\n

Web content audit

\n

The problem:

\n

I often ignore the advice I’m about to share here, because all of my content is perfect and it never ceases to serve a purpose. OK, I know that’s not true, but it’s how I feel about every piece of content I write. And that’s the problem. Getting attached to your content will only serve to hold you back and prevent you from providing your customers with the information they’re looking for.

\n

The solution:

\n

Take stock of what content you have. Ask yourself what content you need. Decide what content you can do without. Think of it like the content Hunger Games. In the end, only the most useful and resourceful content will prevail.

\n

Your business needs and your customers’ needs will change, so your content should be constantly evolving to reflect those needs. Over time, content will lose its relevancy. It’s up to you to determine if content can be updated or repurposed in order to continue providing value, or if the odds are not in the content’s favor and it’s time for it to be retired. (Side note: I’m currently high-fiving myself for including a catchphrase from a book/movie series that I have never read/seen!)

\n

Plan for the future

\n

Use what you learned to help dictate future content

\n

Your analytics will tell you how customers are finding you and what they’re looking for. Don’t fight it, give them what they want. If you don’t someone else will.

\n

Once you have a better understanding of what your customers’ needs are, take the opportunity to update your site’s SEO strategy. Identify critical keywords for which you want to rank highly in web searches and weave them into your content. Just be wary of keyword stuffing.

\n

Create content around larger organizational initiatives

\n

Combine what you’ve learned from the content audit with your organization’s future goal. What upcoming campaigns/product releases can you tie-in with to provide a boost to your website traffic while helping customers address their needs?

\n

Hopefully these tips will help you get your digital house in order and ready to entertain guests, but if you'd like some additional insights, download our Content Consistency Webinar below.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\nSara\n
\n
\nYou're awesome Mike. Great work on this piece.\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\nMike\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Just like sports, websites should be accessible to everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n9/5/12 3:49 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With the Paralympics underway, world coverage of the 2nd biggest multinational event has highlighted how sports should be enjoyed by everyone, regardless of their disability, but what about the accessibility of websites?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9089757164:\n\n\n\n\n\nCase Study: Deakin University\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Deakin University

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for requesting our case study!

\n


Click to Download the case study HERE

\n


This case study gives a brief explanation of how Deakin University uses Siteimprove to manage web content between 200+ active content contributors across 4 campuses.

\n
\n

Like to learn more? Click to Request a Demo

\n

Managing websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content.

\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through:

\n
    \n
  • Web Quality Assurance
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Analytics
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization Analysis
    • \n
  • Web Performance Alerts
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9561294394:\n\n\n\n\n\nOn-Demand Webinar: Including People With Disabilities in Your User Testing\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

On-Demand Webinar: Including People With Disabilities in Your User Testing

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

We’ve talked in the past about having people with disabilities test your webpages. Many of you are interested in doing this, but have asked, “How do I get started?” It doesn’t need to be a complex process, as there are some great resources available if you know where to look, but there are a few different aspects of the process that you will need to consider. 

\n

In this on-demand webinar, we provide some ideas on how to implement a plan for including people with disabilities in your user testing. Topics include:

\n
    \n
  • Getting started
    • \n
  • Recruiting people with disabilities\n
      \n
    • Range of disabilities
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • Test environments - planning, live testing, remote testing
    • \n
  • Learning from and working with people with disabilities
    • \n
  • Reporting results
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n© 2015 Siteimprove Inc\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9084162834:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Accessibility Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nWeb Accessibility Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n

However, many of our most beloved websites choose style over substance when it comes to web accessibility, which means that users with visual or hearing impairments, physical limitations, or cognitive disabilities aren’t able to access and enjoy many of the online experiences that the rest of us take for granted.

\n

Sure, sharing that cat video or the latest meme might be as easy as clicking a few buttons for you or me, but what about the 20% of the world population who live with some form of disability?

\n

For those living with limited motor functions, simply clicking their mouse might actually require a significant effort. Meanwhile, laughing at that video on YouTube isn’t possible for the hearing impaired unless there is a transcript or closed captioning to accompany it.

\n

It’s easy to not think about these things if you or someone you know aren’t affected by web accessibility issues, but luckily for all of us, our technology has reached a point where making websites accessible to everyone is easier than ever, as long as you’re willing to do things the right way.

\n

So, how can you start making your website more accessible today?

\n

Structure your page content correctly

\n

How often do you skim through a web page, or even a newspaper or magazine article, looking for the big headings to find the content that you need? You’re probably doing it right now. Half of the people who landed on this page probably won’t even read this sentence. Their loss.

\n

Well the same goes for assistive devices. They “read” web content following a logical structure. They are literal to a fault if your webpages aren’t structured properly.

\n

For that reason, it’s essential for your webpage to use what’s known as “Semantic Markup” or “Semantic Structure”. WebAIM.org describes website semantic structure in greater depth.

\n

“H” tags

\n

The easiest way to establish semantic structure is with the use of proper Heading Tags or “H tags”.

\n

Headings indicate the importance and hierarchy of your content, and would look something like this:

\n
    \n
  • Heading 1\n
      \n
    • Heading 2\n
        \n
      • Heading 3
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    • Heading 2\n
        \n
      • Heading 3
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Here’s an example of the same heading structure with relevant content:

\n
    \n
  • Web accessibility blogs\n
      \n
    • Awesome blogs\n
        \n
      • Siteimprove
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    • Less awesome blogs\n
        \n
      • Everyone else
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

See? Proper heading structure allows you to navigate information easily and identify the most important information first.

\n

Lists

\n

Another way in which assistive devices navigate web content is through lists. Lists can be Ordered (showing a progression or sequence) or Unordered (no importance of sequence), but should never be used merely for indenting content or for visual effect.

\n

Your lists should always include a description which indicates the contents within. If your list contains links, they should clearly identify the locations to where they will direct the user.

\n

Use proper “alt” attributes on visual content

\n

The “alt” attribute (alternative text) is a crucial element of every image, video, or other non-textual content. The function of the alt text is to provide assistive devices, and search engines, with an accurate description of the visual media being displayed on your website.

\n

Since assistive devices and search engines can’t actually “see” images or video, they identify it by reading the HTML code for <img> or <video> tags. While these tags indicate that an image or video is present, it is the “alt” attribute that describes what is actually being shown on the page.

\n

For example, an <img> tag without an “alt” attribute may look like this:

\n

<img src="images/071014-DSC_01jpg"/>

\n

Not very helpful, is it? A better usage would look more like this:

\n

<img src="images/empire_state_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Empire State Building"/>

\n

As you can see, the “alt” attribute provides a description of what the image is portraying.

\n

You may have also noticed that the image file name was changed. This isn’t a requirement for web accessibility, as assistive devices will skip over the file name if it sees that the “alt” attribute is present, but it seemed lazy to not let you know that providing an accurate file name will benefit your SEO performance. You’re welcome!

\n

Identify link locations

\n

Especially if the link opens in a new window! For users with disabilities, they may not be able to easily identify where a particular link will take them.

\n

Providing a clear description of where links will redirect users is good practice in general, but especially useful for disabled users who rely on assistive devices to navigate web pages.

\n

Many assistive devices allow users to scan webpages by displaying a list of links. This means that they will be skipping the text in between, and lose some of the context surrounding those links.

\n

While the average user might be able to interpret the preceding text to determine where a link that says “Click Here” might take them, an assistive device cannot provide that context and distinguish the link locations for 10 links that all read “Click Here”.

\n

Provide a “skip navigation” link

\n

Sometimes referred to as a “skip to content” link, this option allows disabled users to quickly navigate to their desired content in as few as two keystrokes.

\n

This is an incredibly convenient tool for screen reader users, because screen readers are programmed to automatically begin reading through all of the navigation options on a website first, as they are located at the top of the page. You can imagine how annoying this could be to a screen reader user if your website has 7 navigation dropdown menus which each contain a further 5 navigation options.

\n

The Web Accessibility in Mind (WebAIM) website provides an easy to follow guide for implementing a Skip Navigation link on your webpages.

\n

Consider good design and readability for all users

\n

Not all people with disabilities use assistive technology. Furthermore, proper web design will enhance the experience for all users, even those who are not living with a disability.

\n

We’re not saying that you should only consider function over fashion, but when it comes to web accessibility, visual elements that don’t serve a purpose beyond their cosmetic layer are unlikely to add any value to your website.

\n

As we recently discussed, you can even increase the SEO performance of your website by employing proper coding techniques, logical information architecture, and clear navigation.

\n

Think about it this way- if users without disabilities have trouble navigating your website and finding the information they need, how do you think a disabled user will feel?

\n

Web Accessibility is easier to achieve than many people think. By making a few adjustments to the way you’re already managing your website, you can provide a barrier free experience to all of your users.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\nInvolving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n\n

I'll be hosting a webinar to discuss how you can benefit from involving people with disabilities in your web projects on Wednesday, November 12.

\n

For now, let's take a quick look at some of the topics that I'll be covering.

\n

Accessibility or Usability

\n

First, let's cover the common question of whether an issue is about accessibility or usability. In most cases we can say that it's both. So much of what you do to improve usability has a positive effect on accessibility. For example, a clean, well-designed navigation system makes it easier for all of your users to find the information they are looking for. Usability is concerned with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction—and accessibility is considered a subset of usability—so a website can’t be considered usable unless it’s accessible.

\n

Accessibility covers a range of issues

\n

Many people still see accessibility issues as affecting only a small group of people. In fact, accessibility covers a very broad range of disabilities. On one end of the spectrum, there are those with serious mental or physical disabilities—usually pretty easy to define.

\n

What about the other end? What about people who wear glasses? People who are color-blind? Those who have dyslexia? What about those people who prefer using a keyboard instead of a mouse? Do they fall within the range of disabilities (yes!) and how do you address the issues they may have?

\n

Finding People with Disabilities (PwD)

\n

You’ve made the wise decision to include people with disabilities in your project. What next? “Where can I find a person with a disability?” you may be asking yourself. There are numerous ways to engage people with disabilities, and the ease of finding a willing collaborator may vary according to your industry and type of organization. Don’t fear; there are many great resources available.

\n

For example, if you are working in a higher education environment, check with your campus disability services office. There are students and even faculty or staff members who are willing to participate and can give you excellent feedback.

\n

When do I involve PwD?

\n

Another question that comes up as you engage with your new consultants is when to actually get them involved? From a planning point, be sure to get them involved as quickly as possible. They may not actually sit down and test your site until later in the process, but if you are not planning for their involvement from the beginning of the project, you will run into barriers that you should have already addressed.

\n

During the webinar, we will give you a roadmap to help plan out how and when to involve PwD.

\n

Range of disabilities and the needs of your tester

\n

Be sure you understand the range of disabilities you will be planning and testing for. You may need to address different kinds of disabilities in your user testing, so a variety of software and hardware may need to be assembled before you get started. Your testers can give you specific recommendations based on their experience. You may need to gather hardware or software for:

\n
    \n
  • Keyboard accessibility
    • \n
  • Screenreader accessibility
    • \n
  • Cognitive accessibility
    • \n
\n

Working with People with Disabilities

\n

A little planning and knowledge of working with people with disabilities will make your web project flow quite smoothly. Considerations may include how you plan your testing location, what conclusions you hope to gain, and a few matters of etiquette.

\n

It’s possible that you already have a suitable test environment already set up. Just be sure your accommodations for people with disabilities are really no different than you normally plan: a comfortable environment, which allows your tester to concentrate on the tasks you give them. That said, never make assumptions, speak normally, and always be aware of personal space. Given the proper setting, you will be amazed at the conclusions your testers provide.

\n

Be sure to carefully consider all feedback and avoid assuming that feedback from one person with a disability applies to all people with disabilities. A person with a disability does not necessarily know how other people with the same disability interact with the web, nor know enough about other disabilities to provide valid guidance on other accessibility issues.

\n

In this month’s web accessibility webinar, we’re going to build on these ideas of including people with disabilities in your web project. We will cover the topic in more detail and help you figure out some ways to gain even more important insights. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

  • \nJuly 2013 (3)\n

  • \nMay 2013 (3)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2013 (4)\n
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9568711364:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Study: The State of Canadian Legal Websites\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Website Study: The State of Canadian Legal Websites

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove used their Web Governance suite to collect information from the websites of 53 of Canada's most prominent law firms. The results are summarized in this study. The study has been broken down into 34 Small and Mid-Sized firms, and 29 Large firms. 

\n

This study provides benchmarking for your legal service's website quality standards. Issues examined in this study:

\n
    \n
  • Broken links
    • \n
  • Misspellings
    • \n
  • SEO-damaging issues
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility errors
    • \n
\n



\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8902092344:\n\n\n\n\n\nUsing Web Analytics To Improve Your Content\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nUsing Web Analytics To Improve Your Content\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n

Analytics and web content go together like metaphors and comparing things. Personally, I think this blog is radical and that every person who reads it will think the same thing, but I won’t know for sure until I see the analytics data. Your website’s analytics data will provide you with everything you need to know about your audience- who they are, how they got to your site, and what they did once they got there.

\n

Let’s take a look at some of the analytics segments that can help you improve your site’s content immediately.

\n

Traffic Sources

\n

Understanding where your website’s visitors are coming from will allow you to tailor your messaging for specific channels and decide where to focus your marketing efforts. If you’re seeing a spike in traffic from online searches for a specific keyword, don’t be afraid to give people more of what they want.

\n

In most cases, visitors aren’t reaching your website through the front door. Online searches often lead visitors to your 2nd and 3rd tier pages where the content is focused on a specific topic. This is important to keep in mind when developing page content as SEO applies to every page on your site, so be sure that every page has a clearly defined purpose.

\n

Your analytics will also show you when and where visitors are leaving your site, allowing you to identify pages that present potential roadblocks, or aren’t providing the information they need.

\n

Page Views

\n

Numbers don’t lie. They're actually brutally honest. If a page has high traffic, it’s safe to assume that the content is hitting the mark with your audience, while pages with low traffic may need some special attention.

\n

The one thing numbers don’t provide is context, so be aware of the bounce rate on pages with high traffic. A high bounce rate indicates that visitors are leaving your site without going to any additional pages. This should be concerning for pages that are intended to push visitors further into your site, but should be expected on dead end pages like Confirmation or Thank You pages.

\n

Use your analytics to help you determine if a particular page should be given a more prominent position within the site, if the content could benefit from an update, or if the page is ready to be retired.

\n

User Flow/Journey

\n

Getting visitors to your site is one thing. Getting them to stay is another story. Creating content that leads visitors deeper into your site or through the sales funnel is crucial to converting leads into sales and establishing your organization as a trusted resource.

\n

User Flow or User Journey data will allow you to see how visitors are moving around your site. For a University, an example of a user journey might look something like this:

\n

Homepage > Academics > Marketing > Courses > Course Schedule > Admissions > Undergraduate Application > Fall2014_Undergraduate_Application.PDF

\n

Take some time to determine your “ideal” user journeys. That way, you’ll be able to identify any potential weak links in the chain where users are abandoning the journey, or moving backwards. This can be an indication that the content isn’t clearly presented, or isn’t what they were looking for.

\n

Device and Operating Systems

\n

It’s important to know how people are consuming your content. Most analytics platforms will allow you to segment data based on the operating system (Windows, Mac/iOS, Android, Linux) and/or device (Desktop, Laptop, Mobile/Tablet).

\n

Knowing which device your visitors are using is an important distinction to make because content still needs to be presented differently between desktop/laptop and mobile/tablet.

\n

Desktop users are more likely to have the time and desire to read through a lengthy article or complex case study. They’re also able to consume media-rich content like embedded videos and presentations.

\n

Mobile users on the other hand are more likely to benefit from shorter content that gets straight to the point. Mobile experiences can also be hindered by pages that are jam-packed with large images and videos that require long load times.

\n

Spend some quality time with your analytics data and it will weave quite the tale about your website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

The 'Governance' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n5/14/13 3:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

According to Google CEO, Eric Schmidt, every two days now we create as much content as we did from the dawn of civilization up until 2003. While this mind numbing figure may scare off those considering how to govern content, the last installment in our content strategy series will show how with a clear plan, and the assistance of some clever tools, navigating this mammoth task doesn't need to take you a millennium.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Publication' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/22/13 4:04 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Having your content published was once difficult, yet with the emergence of the new media age entry requirements have almost all but disappeared. Instead, the internet has made it possible for almost everyone to share their content, but this isn’t without risks.

\n
\n
\n

With the increasing digitization of the business world, it has now become essential for organizations to become publishers in order to compete against competitors, and gain attention from their target audiences. Yet haphazard publishing can be dangerous for an organization's reputation, especially if standards of reliability, accountability, accuracy and trust slip.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The 'Creation' Component of Content Strategy Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n4/16/13 4:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Previously we introduced the concept of ‘content strategy,’ and explained the three essential components that constitute its lifecycle – creation, publication, and governance. In this blog, will delve deeper into how Siteimprove can assist you during the first component: ‘creation.’

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The three components of Content Strategy success

\n

\nPosted by\nJack Oldham\n

\n

\n4/8/13 2:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n

    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Creating effective website content can be an arduous task, especially when so many factors must be considered: varying role capacities, internal politics, customer expectations etc. However, following a structured strategy can make creating focused content a piece of cake!

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

Ensuring the last laugh isn't at your expense

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/6/13 4:16 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

We all enjoy having a good laugh at spelling mistakes, but the real challenge for those responsible for websites is ensuring that the last laugh isn’t at your expense.

\n
\n
\n

Maintaining your website's credibility is not easy, especially given that for most of us checking spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and broken links is hardly our must-have hobby for 2013, however if you wish to ensure your website's success it is essential.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Applying Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance Policies and Procedures

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n12/5/12 3:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Where would an employee go with questions to how a specific task is done on your website?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Use Web Governance to Secure a Strong Foundation for Your Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n11/28/12 3:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Who is in control of your internal search? If you want your search to work well you should include it in your web governance.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

Five Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/30/13 2:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

Web Accessibility and the Law

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/28/14 2:17 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

There is a difference between web accessibility and web usability. For web users with disabilities, the difference often turns their experience with websites into a “yeah, but…” scenario. Yes, the website is technically accessible, but is it usable? Meaning, can the site be navigated in a logical way and can information be accessed with the least amount of obstacles possible? The difference is small on paper, but stark in practice.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Web Governance Food Pyramid

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Foundations of a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Cognitive Disabilities and Website Accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n8/12/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

While sight and hearing disabilities are the most talked-about when it comes to website accessibility, cognitive disabilities actually represent the largest number of computer users with disabilities according to the National Center on Disability and Access to Education.

\n

So, why aren’t we more aware of cognitive disabilities? Well, because these types of disabilities contain a wide range of nuanced conditions and an even wider range of severity, so it’s difficult to present a comprehensive set of standards to which web developers should comply. 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Higher Education & The Web: Reaching Your Audience

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/7/14 10:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Finding the right medium for communicating with the most tech-savvy generations can be difficult. With the abundance of devices, platforms, and channels available to students these days, universities and colleges are forced to make difficult choices. Do they focus their attention on a select number of channels, or do they try to spread their efforts across as many as possible in the hopes of reaching the largest audience possible? There may not be a single right answer for every institution, but recent trends should help make finding those answers easier.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792119024:\n\n\n\n\n\nStep 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nStep 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n

Don’t worry, non-English majors, writing well doesn’t mean transforming yourself into the second-coming of Hemmingway, Twain, or Dickinson. You don’t need to fill your paragraphs with complicated prose. Complex writing does not equal good writing. Good writing is simply the result of a clear message, proper grammar and punctuation, and approachability.

\n

So, how can you turn good writing into great web content?

\n

Be original.

\n

If writing well is the foundation, then original writing is the neon-green paint job. It’s what gets you noticed, makes you memorable, and sets you apart from the competition.

\n

Have a voice. Say something different. Say the same thing, but say it better. However you do it, you need to do it in a way that stands out. Be smart, be funny, maybe even a little controversial. Whatever voice you settle on, make sure it’s the one that will resonate with your audience.

\n

If you’re writing for a university who’s trying to appeal to a younger audience, you could explore using verbiage that’s a little more trendy. If you’re writing for a bank, a snarky attitude isn’t likely to convey the level of professionalism that people expect from the institution to which they’ll be entrusting their life savings.

\n

Your company is unique. Write like it.

\n

Give people a reason to care.

\n

Sure, you might be funny or knowledgeable, but that alone won’t keep your readers’ interest. Humor without substance might make a few folks in the cube farm try to smother that giggle, but without a tangible takeaway they’ll probably forget about it once they close their browser window.

\n

On the other side of the coin, being dull and long-winded is a surefire way to bore your readers and send your website’s bounce rate through the roof. 30 pages of research and hard work won’t mean anything if people don’t stick around long enough to read it.

\n

Of course you want people to read your content in the here and now, but you also want them to come back later, you want them to tell others, and you want them all to crave more. With every piece of content you write, ask yourself, “why should anyone care about this?”

\n

People come to your site looking for help, answers, or solutions. It’s your job to show them why you’re the answer to their problem. You need to make people want to do business with you.

\n

Get to the point

\n

The average adult attention span is now eight seconds. That’s one second less than a goldfish.

\n

Don't waste words, but don't gloss over important information.

\n

Say what needs to be said, say it clearly, and let people get on with their day.

\n

Please and thank you.

\n

Be real.

\n

People can tell when they’re being sold to, marketed to, or talked down to. If your content is dishonest, misleading, or patronizing, your audience will tune out long before any usable information is able to sink in. The only thing they’ll remember is the bad experience that they had with your site/company.

\n

Your content should feel natural when it’s being read. Imagine what you would say to your audience if you were having a face-to-face conversation, then write it. You’ll be surprised by how effective content can be when it’s not loaded with sales jargon and marketing catchphrases.

\n

Once you've turned your good writing into great content, make sure it's reaching your audience with this helpful SEO Checklist

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792121764:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n5 Reasons Why Your Website Content Isn’t Influencing Readers\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/1/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Humanizing the digital world is no simple task. Thanks to the rapid advances in technology, the expansion of social media, and the ever growing influence of the Internet, consumers are growing more and more savvy by the day. They also have more choices than ever before, which means you have more competition than ever before. So the question becomes, how to distance yourself from competitors and convince consumers that your product/service/organization is the best option for them?

\n\n

The answer lies in your content. Content is the currency of the digital generation. Once upon a time, companies were able to buy customers simply by spending the most money on advertising and mass marketing. Now, it’s the companies who spend time creating valuable, engaging content that earn customers. The content you share online is an opportunity to show off your brand personality, demonstrate your knowledge, and engage with your audience. Writing dry, lifeless content will bore your readers and prevent them from making a meaningful connection with your organization.

\n

So. What are some reasons why your web content isn’t resonating with your targeted audience?

\n

It’s Not Engaging

\n

For one reason or another, readers aren’t making a connection with you or your content. The digital generation has terrible A.D.D, so you need to give them a reason to stick around. Make it entertaining, give it a personality, anything to make readers remember their experience. For example: If you’re a bank, provide your readers with some eye-opening statistics about retirement planning and they’ll be more likely to look for more information or give you a call.

\n

It’s Not Relevant

\n

Your content could be Pulitzer Prize winning stuff, but if it’s not written for the correct audience, the only “likes” you’ll be getting will be from mom and dad. Listen to your audience and tailor your content based on their needs. For example: Health care providers could share the results of a new medical study on cancer, or how they recently invested in new, cutting-edge technology to demonstrate their commitment to providing top quality care.

\n

It’s Too “Salesy”

\n

Your readers are looking for answers and guidance, not to be sold to. When they’re ready to buy, they’ll let you know. Until then, nurture their needs by providing them with useful information to keep them interested, and to keep your brand at the front of the pack. Telling readers how your product/service is the answer to their problems, without actually proving why, won’t get you very far and is likely to leave a bad taste in the reader’s mouth. Pay it forward, people.

\n

It’s Overbearing

\n

There’s two possibilities here: the first is that you’re bombarding your readers with constant updates and they’re getting burnt out. The second is that your content is too dense and you’re running into “too long; didn’t read” syndrome. Remember to keep your content focused, spread out your updates/notifications, and if you have A LOT of information consider breaking it up into a series of smaller updates.

\n

It Doesn’t Empathize

\n

This goes back to the idea of making a human connection with your readers. If your content makes readers say, “Hey, we have that same problem!” Bam. You've got them hooked. Your goal should be to show them that you understand their challenge, and that you have the information/solution that they’re looking for. For example: A college or university could appeal to potential students who also work full-time by communicating how a busy schedule shouldn't prevent them from getting access to a good education, which is why they’ve created flexible and online courses in order to help students find time for both work and education.

\n

 

\n

Your website content is crucial to reaching your online goals, but you’ll only reach them if it resonates with your audience as well.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792122154:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Governance Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
