\n

\nThe Web Governance Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/22/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every organization has different goals for their online presence, a unique team managing that presence, and a distinct process for achieving their goals. What I’m trying to say, is that there’s no golden ticket, silver bullet, or metaphor in the world that will solve every organization’s web governance needs. However, there are plenty of ways to get your web governance endeavors started off on the right (or left) foot.

\n

Whether you’re just getting your organization’s web governance strategy in place, or need to get yours back to basics, here are a few areas to focus on.

\n\n

Goals

\n

Does your website know what it wants to be when it grows up? In other words, what do you want to accomplish with your online presence? Is it to drive sales, boost brand awareness, share information, or act as a digital portal for customers to pay bills and enroll in classes?

\n

Your content should be focused on reaching a specific audience for a specific reason, so be sure to identify the “who” and the “why” before you begin creating content. When you know where you’re going, it makes it easier to plan out how you’ll get there.

\n

Roles & Responsibilities

\n

“I thought you were doing that.” When you hear those words, it’s already too late. Answering the question of “Who does what?” is vital to helping your team avoid confusion, streamline workflows, and maximize their efficiency.

\n

If you’re a one person team, this doesn’t apply to you, but know that we’re all tipping our collective caps in your general direction for your courage.

\n

For the rest of you, identifying the team members who are responsible for addressing issues like broken links, outdated content, or web accessibility errors will ensure that tasks can be completed quickly and without confusion or debate. Luckily, our good friend Shane Diffily explained how to address roles and responsibilities on growing web teams in a recent blog. 

\n

It’s important to keep your lines of communication open. Just because a particular team or team member is or isn’t responsible for something, doesn’t mean they shouldn’t be communicating their efforts to the rest of the web management team. This way, everyone will know when an issue is has been addressed, and if the issue manages to spill over into other areas.

\n

Policies, Standards, and Processes

\n

Establishing clearly defined policies for how and when content is, created/updated/removed standards for content quality, and the process for doing so will make your job less of a guessing game.

\n

Policies

\n

Web governance policies are meant to be high level guidelines which impact the entire organization and every online channel, from your website and blog, to your social media and emails. Policies should be few in number and only change when absolutely necessary or to reflect a seismic shift in organizational goals.

\n

Standards

\n

Web standards are more specific rules and qualifications which determine things like the voice and tone of content, the look and feel of design elements, or the specific channels and tools used to communicate your message.

\n

Processes

\n

Processes dictate the order and steps that need to be taken in order to add, update, or remove content from your online channels.

\n

Developing an editorial calendar will help you plan out these updates and provide you with ample time to monitor their success in order to determine what changes need to be made and when.

\n

Monitor, Manage, and Maintain

\n

SPOILER ALERT: Shameless plug time.

\n

Employing a web governance tool like Siteimprove will help your web team monitor mountains of content and data with the click of a button. By using our software to scan your site for broken links, misspellings, and content consistency, your team will be able to save time and focus on creating a web experience that will help your organization reach its online goals.

\n

Download our helpful checklist to get your Web Governance Strategy moving in the right direction.

\n

 

\n

  \n \n \n

\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Using Web Analytics To Improve Your Content

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Ask Us Anything Preview

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/15/14 12:48 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We're in a giving mood today, so we thought we'd share a quick preview of what you can expect to learn from our upcoming Ask Us Anything session.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Make Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

\n

\n3 ways to improve your accessibility right now\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n\n

1. Give your web pages meaningful titles

\n

By providing all your web pages with a meaningful page title, you help both users and search engines. Use a tool that can easily identify pages with missing titles for you. Make sure to provide these pages with a title, and also go through a selection of your existing page titles to assess whether they are descriptive enough for the content on the page.

\n

The first thing a screen reader encounters when a web page is opened is the page title. The title is an important element on a page for screen reader users, because it informs them of the content they can expect to find on the page.

\n

By providing your web pages with meaningful titles you are in conformance with WCAG success criterion 2.4.2 Page Titled: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.

\n

2. Provide support for users who cannot use a computer mouse

\n

Create a link that is present on all your web pages as the first element on the page. This link should take the user directly to the page content (skipping for instance the global menu). This way users with visual impairments, motor impairments and other types of users using a screen reader, or who navigate from the keyboard alone can skip repeated blocks of information.

\n

You can hide the link visually on the page if you like, as long as it's still visible when it receives focus [Wikipedia link]. (e.g. highlighted when a user presses the "Tab" button)

\n

By helping users who cannot use a computer mouse you are in conformance with WCAG success criterion 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages.

\n

3. Review the images on your main pages

\n

Go through your main page and your template pages and assess whether the images should have alternative texts. The code for alternative text (alt="") must always be present for any image, however, if the image is decorative the alt text field can be left empty. If the image conveys information that you would not know without seeing the image, then this information should be written in the alternative text. If the image is a link, then describe the destination to where the link takes you.

\n

There are many tools available to help you identify and highlight alternative texts, such as Siteimprove Accessibility or free toolbars.  AbilityNet provides a list of some of these free accessibility toolbars.

\n

When working on alternative texts for images, you are conforming with an essential part of WCAG success criterion 1.1.1 Non-text Content: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose (with a number of exceptions).

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

Recent Posts

\n

Watch Out, Australia. Here Comes Kelsey.

\n

\nPosted by\nKelsey Johnson\n

\n

\n10/14/14 5:30 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Well, I’m headed down under, to Oz, Aussie, or whatever you prefer to call it – Let me try that again… I’m going to Australia!

\n

Over the past year I’ve had the immense pleasure of working with the Oceania region, and it’s about time that I dropped in for a visit! I’ve been fortunate to build a great network of customers, influencers, and web experts across Australia that I cannot wait to meet with and discuss how Siteimprove can continue to support the needs of web teams around the world, and more specifically, in Australia.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n

\n
\n

\nWeb Analytics & Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n\n
\n

Unfortunately, many organizations have access to lots of analytical data but fail to apply it into something useful. This is both because they don't know how to sort such a large amount of data, and also because it's unclear who has ownership of the web analytics.

\n

Without specified ownership, the web analytics tasks tend to fall through the cracks. It's far too easy for them to become something you look at once in a while just to find out how many visitors you have had the last month, or the top 10 most visited pages.

\n

Roles and responsibilities

\n

Initiating your organization's web governance is a difficult task, requiring a lot of planning ahead.  If you're wondering where to start, the first step is to determine roles and responsibilities.

\n

Depending on your level of ambition and how large your organization is, there are a number of different roles to be distributed among your team. Here's an example of a basic set of roles to be set for any organization:

\n
    \n
  • Technical Officer - Responsible for the technical implementation of web analytics tools and collecting data in the parameters that stakeholders want to be measured.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Method responsible - Works in coordination with the Technical Officer and spokesman of stakeholders to ensure that the organization uses a correct and unified approaches to web analytics. Ensures that all results across the organization can be compared and checked against each other.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Spokesman for the web analytics users - Must represent the different parts of the organization with an interest in using and working with web analytics. This can include editors, management or other webmasters. The spokesman's responsibilities include ensuring that the proper web analytics data is produced, and also that the data available is consistent with the stakeholders' wishes.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Analyst / Consultant - Must provide analysis and reports to users based on the standards and methods as the "Method responsible" has defined. In addition the person shall act as a consultant to assist in the understanding and application of the possibilities in the web analytics. 
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Steering committee for web analytics - Consisting of three people who have the overall picture of who holds the different roles and the organization's policies, web strategy and that the organization standards are constantly met.
    • \n
\n

One person can fulfill several of these roles, and the ambition and size of each organization will determine the roles and responsibility of each team member.

\n

Strategy of planning of web analytics

\n

After roles are distributed and everyone is aware of their responsibility, a working strategy for the organization's web analytics should be created. The strategy will primarily be used to clarify where and how to move your web presence in the right direction, and what you want to achieve by doing it. It should also help ensure that everyone in the organization has a common understanding and is working towards the same goal.

\n

If there isn't a clear strategy and the planning isn't thought through and working in practice, this is where the project falls apart.

\n

In my next blog post I will make suggestions for how to approach the whole process of planning and making strategy for your web analytics. But it's vital that you base that web analytics strategy on your overall web strategy. Otherwise, you will quickly find yourself working against the overall goals of your organization.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792135424:\n\n\n\n\n\n3 Things you can do to improve your internal search\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\n3 Things you can do to improve your internal search\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n\n

Three things you can do to begin with:

\n
    \n
  • Build bridges between the terms that your users use and the terms on the website
    There is often a difference. What you call "bin collection" might be called "rubbish" by your users. One way of dealing with this is to integrate the terms used by your audience on the webpage.
    If a term should not be used on the website, the search engine can be set up to expand a search query for that term and search for the synonym present on the website as well.
    • \n
  • Give the search results relevant and specific titles
    The best place to do this is on the page itself - either in the title or the heading. If that is not possible you might be able to adjust the titles shown in your internal search tool.
    • \n
  • Make sure the most relevant pages are being ranked highest.
    Your search tool should be in line with the strategy for the website in general. If the goal for your website is for the users to use self service options, self service pages should be ranked highest, followed by pages with background information about the service. If your websites main goal is to promote the skills of the people working there, person profiles should of course be ranked highest. Sometimes there will be a need to refer to an external website or one your subsites that is relevant to the query at hand.
    In most cases minutes, forum posts and old news should be ranked low, so they only display if not other information is relevant for a query.
    • \n
\n

If your start working on these three points, a small effort will get you a long way!

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792135684:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy is web analytics important?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWhy is web analytics important?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/4/12 11:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

What can analytics do for your site performance and business goals?

\n
\n\n

Why web analytics is important for your website

\n

Whether your website is a storefront, an informational site, or a mixture of both, web analytics is necessary to determine whether or not you're hitting your objectives.

Additionally, web analytics can be used for future development of your web strategy, so you can ensure a continuous improvement of the user experience on your website.

\n

Web analytics defines your online strategy

\n

Web analytics is more than just installing a script on a website and setting up a monthly report to show the number of visitors on your site. Web analytics requires analysis. The numbers that your analytics tool delivers must be interpreted before they have any real value for making informed decisions.

Thorough usage of analytical data provides a much greater understanding of the users on a website. This understanding of users is crucial to developing an online strategy for any website.

Whether your goal is to tailor the website to the user's needs or to get users to change their behavior, what's important is to know how the users use the website now. This allows you to optimize your online strategy and define future goals.

\n

Set objectives with ongoing analytics

\n

Web analytics is a cyclical process that should run concurrently with the ongoing development and optimization of a website. It's therefore important to constantly analyze and document how user behavior changes when making improvements on a website.

An example of a simple objective in an online strategy is to get more users to read the FAQ in the hope that there are fewer users that will contact the company for answers to questions, because the answer actually already available on the website. A very simple objective, but can be quite effective if it can help to reduce the manual operation of customers, and simultaneously it's easy to measure if you have the proper documentation of the user behavior.
 

\n

Don't fumble around in the dark

\n

If you aren't using a web analytics tool there's really no way of knowing whether you're moving closer to your goal or further away from it. This is just one reason that ongoing analysis and documentation of changes in user behavior is critical to running a good website that meets the company's online strategy.

Another benefit is that web analytics and documentation of the user behavior is a powerful tool for demonstrating the ROI of developing the website and securing funding for further improvements.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792151574:\n\n\n\n\n\n4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n4 Website Tasks You Should Outsource to Robots\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/23/13 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Every web team is strapped for time, but most have no idea how much time they waste doing things manually when automated options are readily available. Here are four ways you’re wasting time maintaining your organization’s website.

\n

Web Error Checking

\n

Error checking is arguably the most obvious and important task in this list, because waiting for someone to complain about a mistake on your site isn’t a great “plan A.” It’s stressful, and the complaints always seem to come at the wrong time - to your boss, who freaks out.

\n

Strangely, while most seasoned web managers have experienced this scenario, most have never set up any real method of preventing it. Sure, your CMS has a spell check, but that doesn’t account for human error.

\n

If your CMS’s dictionary doesn’t have all your organization’s unique terminology, the web team will be ignoring the warnings faster than you can say “gosh, it would sure be swell if you guys could tell the difference between ‘their’ and ‘there.’”

\n

At the end of the day, the vast majority of organizations expect their web teams to manually comb through the site to find errors, which is a huge time sink and still doesn’t get the site 100% clean.

\n

It’s 2014. Humanity has landed robots on mars with self-piloting rocket cranes, created living human organs with a printer, and invented automatic methods of catching errors on your website. 

\n

Let the robots handle this so you can spend your time on more important things, like staying up to date on the internet’s astounding volume of silly cat videos.

\n

Web Analytics Reporting

\n

Status reports kill productivity. Generally, you can either do work or tell people about it.

\n

Unfortunately for you, lots of people need to see what’s going on with the website because it affects their work. They don’t all care about the same sections, so if you plan to include everyone you’re going to spend a ton of time creating custom reports.

\n

Automating your analytics reports is a silver bullet for time-sucking status reports. Everyone can see what’s happening with the website, and after the initial setup you don’t have to lift a finger to make it happen.

\n

When everyone is well informed about what’s happening with the website, they’re way more likely to stay engaged in website upkeep. Nobody likes working on something without ever seeing results.

\n

Let the robots have this one too.

\n

Web Inventories

\n

Many organizations routinely waste hundreds of hours taking inventory of all the media, links, etc. on their websites.

\n

To be clear, inventories aren’t a waste. Without them you might never catch the fact that Carol from Accounting is still listed under the “Contact Billing” form even though she retired last year. The waste is spending a month of man-hours getting it done.

\n

Again: space robots and designer internal organs. 
Modern technology has progressed to where you can scan your site and get a complete inventory with the click of a single button – and if you get the right tools, you don’t even have to click a button. Homer Simpson would be so proud.

\n

Web Governance Enforcement

\n

Consistency is key when establishing a web presence for your organization because the little things add up.  Should your phone numbers be formatted with dots or dashes? What’s the maximum file size allowed for uploaded photos? How do you catch hotlinked images?

\n

Instead of having a human try to give a once-over to every page created, let a robot do it. They’re fast, accurate, and unlike an intern they’ll never send you results formatted as a bunch of discombobulated screenshots dumped into a Microsoft Word document.

\n

So quit wasting your time doing things manually when there are perfectly good robots to do it for you.  Click here to check out what Siteimprove can automate for you.

\n

Do you know of a method of automation we haven’t mentioned here? Let us know in the comments.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Helene Nørgaard Bech

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

3 ways to improve your accessibility right now

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/9/12 11:11 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It can be difficult to know where to start if you have not implemented web accessibility before. Where do you begin and how do you finish? Some areas require time and a targeted effort whilst there are some ways in which you can improve your website accessibility right away, and at the same time conform with 3 important criteria in WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The added bonus of ensuring web accessibility

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n5/2/12 11:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you looking to attract more visitors and retain happier users of your website? If so, then read on! By conforming with a number of accessibility criteria you can not only optimize the accessibility of your website, but also ensure good usability and increased visibility in search engines (SEO).

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What is Web Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n3/21/12 11:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

The term “Accessibility” is often used broadly, but there is a clear definition of what we mean: ensuring that as many users as possible can navigate and comprehend a website.

\n
\n

Being in the accessibility industry, I meet many web professionals with differing thoughts on what web accessibility is. Some think that it's all about uptime and response time (Availability), others say usability, and some say search engine optimization (SEO) or "find-ability." Some believe that accessibility means that everything on your website can be read aloud in an automated way. I think you get the idea.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792128054:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Accessibility Checklist\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nWeb Accessibility Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/23/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Our reliance on technology in everyday life continues to grow at an alarming rate. I’m willing to wager that the majority of you are reading this on a computer, your smartphone is within arm’s reach, there’s a tablet tucked away in your bag, and you may have even snuck in some TV time today. Some of our closest relationships are the ones we have with our screens and devices, floating in the pixelated waves of the digital sea. Despite how we may feel about being so reliant on our technology, there’s no denying the benefits offered by the latest and greatest gear, gadgets, and gizmos.

\n

\n

However, many of our most beloved websites choose style over substance when it comes to web accessibility, which means that users with visual or hearing impairments, physical limitations, or cognitive disabilities aren’t able to access and enjoy many of the online experiences that the rest of us take for granted.

\n

Sure, sharing that cat video or the latest meme might be as easy as clicking a few buttons for you or me, but what about the 20% of the world population who live with some form of disability?

\n

For those living with limited motor functions, simply clicking their mouse might actually require a significant effort. Meanwhile, laughing at that video on YouTube isn’t possible for the hearing impaired unless there is a transcript or closed captioning to accompany it.

\n

It’s easy to not think about these things if you or someone you know aren’t affected by web accessibility issues, but luckily for all of us, our technology has reached a point where making websites accessible to everyone is easier than ever, as long as you’re willing to do things the right way.

\n

So, how can you start making your website more accessible today?

\n

Structure your page content correctly

\n

How often do you skim through a web page, or even a newspaper or magazine article, looking for the big headings to find the content that you need? You’re probably doing it right now. Half of the people who landed on this page probably won’t even read this sentence. Their loss.

\n

Well the same goes for assistive devices. They “read” web content following a logical structure. They are literal to a fault if your webpages aren’t structured properly.

\n

For that reason, it’s essential for your webpage to use what’s known as “Semantic Markup” or “Semantic Structure”. WebAIM.org describes website semantic structure in greater depth.

\n

“H” tags

\n

The easiest way to establish semantic structure is with the use of proper Heading Tags or “H tags”.

\n

Headings indicate the importance and hierarchy of your content, and would look something like this:

\n
    \n
  • Heading 1\n
      \n
    • Heading 2\n
        \n
      • Heading 3
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    • Heading 2\n
        \n
      • Heading 3
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

Here’s an example of the same heading structure with relevant content:

\n
    \n
  • Web accessibility blogs\n
      \n
    • Awesome blogs\n
        \n
      • Siteimprove
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    • Less awesome blogs\n
        \n
      • Everyone else
        • \n
      \n
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
\n

See? Proper heading structure allows you to navigate information easily and identify the most important information first.

\n

Lists

\n

Another way in which assistive devices navigate web content is through lists. Lists can be Ordered (showing a progression or sequence) or Unordered (no importance of sequence), but should never be used merely for indenting content or for visual effect.

\n

Your lists should always include a description which indicates the contents within. If your list contains links, they should clearly identify the locations to where they will direct the user.

\n

Use proper “alt” attributes on visual content

\n

The “alt” attribute (alternative text) is a crucial element of every image, video, or other non-textual content. The function of the alt text is to provide assistive devices, and search engines, with an accurate description of the visual media being displayed on your website.

\n

Since assistive devices and search engines can’t actually “see” images or video, they identify it by reading the HTML code for <img> or <video> tags. While these tags indicate that an image or video is present, it is the “alt” attribute that describes what is actually being shown on the page.

\n

For example, an <img> tag without an “alt” attribute may look like this:

\n

<img src="images/071014-DSC_01jpg"/>

\n

Not very helpful, is it? A better usage would look more like this:

\n

<img src="images/empire_state_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Empire State Building"/>

\n

As you can see, the “alt” attribute provides a description of what the image is portraying.

\n

You may have also noticed that the image file name was changed. This isn’t a requirement for web accessibility, as assistive devices will skip over the file name if it sees that the “alt” attribute is present, but it seemed lazy to not let you know that providing an accurate file name will benefit your SEO performance. You’re welcome!

\n

Identify link locations

\n

Especially if the link opens in a new window! For users with disabilities, they may not be able to easily identify where a particular link will take them.

\n

Providing a clear description of where links will redirect users is good practice in general, but especially useful for disabled users who rely on assistive devices to navigate web pages.

\n

Many assistive devices allow users to scan webpages by displaying a list of links. This means that they will be skipping the text in between, and lose some of the context surrounding those links.

\n

While the average user might be able to interpret the preceding text to determine where a link that says “Click Here” might take them, an assistive device cannot provide that context and distinguish the link locations for 10 links that all read “Click Here”.

\n

Provide a “skip navigation” link

\n

Sometimes referred to as a “skip to content” link, this option allows disabled users to quickly navigate to their desired content in as few as two keystrokes.

\n

This is an incredibly convenient tool for screen reader users, because screen readers are programmed to automatically begin reading through all of the navigation options on a website first, as they are located at the top of the page. You can imagine how annoying this could be to a screen reader user if your website has 7 navigation dropdown menus which each contain a further 5 navigation options.

\n

The Web Accessibility in Mind (WebAIM) website provides an easy to follow guide for implementing a Skip Navigation link on your webpages.

\n

Consider good design and readability for all users

\n

Not all people with disabilities use assistive technology. Furthermore, proper web design will enhance the experience for all users, even those who are not living with a disability.

\n

We’re not saying that you should only consider function over fashion, but when it comes to web accessibility, visual elements that don’t serve a purpose beyond their cosmetic layer are unlikely to add any value to your website.

\n

As we recently discussed, you can even increase the SEO performance of your website by employing proper coding techniques, logical information architecture, and clear navigation.

\n

Think about it this way- if users without disabilities have trouble navigating your website and finding the information they need, how do you think a disabled user will feel?

\n

Web Accessibility is easier to achieve than many people think. By making a few adjustments to the way you’re already managing your website, you can provide a barrier free experience to all of your users.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\nWebsite SEO Checklist\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n\n

Riveting stuff, right? Now that you’re part of the SEO “in” crowd, and you know how important it is to focus on creating relevant, high-quality content, let’s take a look at a few behind-the-scenes elements of your website that have an impact on SEO.

\n

Keywords

\n

These little guys represent the main topics or ideas that you want your site/pages to rank highly for in organic web searches. Keep in mind that common or popular keywords will often come with a lot of competition, so try to focus on keywords that are specific to your organization/industry.

\n

The best way to identify your keywords is to ask yourself, “who is our audience?” When you know who you’re trying to reach, and why you’re trying to reach them, you’ll be able to understand what questions they have and what they may be searching for online.

\n

Each page on your website should try to focus on a single keyword for maximum effect. You should also be sure to include the keyword in each of these areas:

\n
    \n
  • Page URL
    • \n
  • Meta Description
    • \n
  • Title Tags
    • \n
  • Heading Tags
    • \n
  • Relevant image descriptions and Alt Tags
    • \n
\n

\n

Title Tags (Page Titles)

\n

Title tags tell people and search engines what content they can find on a page. Keep these short and sweet, and don’t mislead people by jamming 10 different keywords into a title tag, this will only hurt you in the long run.

\n

Instead, focus on a single keyword and keep title tags under 65 characters for the best results. Also, try to place your targeted keyword for the page towards the beginning of the page title.

\n

\n

Meta Descriptions

\n

Like Title Tags, Meta Descriptions explain the content that can be found on a page, but with a longer description/summary than the Title Tag. These should always include the keyword that you’re trying to rank for and never exceed 160 characters.

\n

Meta descriptions should be unique for each page. Simply swapping out the keyword will lead search engines to think that your page content is all the same.

\n

\n

Heading Tags

\n

Heading tags allow people and search engines to identify the main topic(s) on a page. Be sure to structure your “H tags” properly based on high level topics and sub topics so that your page structure follows a logical flow. Not everything on your page can, or should, fall under an H1 tag

\n

For example, a page about Chocolate Desserts (stay focused) would feature “Chocolate Desserts” as the main heading/H1 tag, while listing sub topics like “Cake”, “Cookies”, and “Ice Cream” as the H2 tags. Different varieties of cake, cookies, and ice cream would then fall under their respective category as “H3” tags, and so on.

\n

\n

Page Links

\n

Outbound Links

\n

Linking out to other sites with good reputations (i.e- sites with quality content) will also boost your search rankings. Google’s Hummingbird update has placed a focus on providing web users with the best possible information, which means that if your site is linking out to the New York Times, your SEO ranking will be boosted more than if you were to link out to Jim’s News (sorry Jim).

\n

Be sure to avoid stuffing your site with links. Google’s head of WebSpam, Matt Cutts, recently shared some insights on the amount of links per page.

\n

Internal Links

\n

Internal links are also important as they indicate the destination of text and image hyperlinks to both users and search engines. The two elements you’ll want to focus on are Anchor Text and Destination Pages.

\n

Anchor Text  & Destination Pages

\n

Anchor Text is the on page text that indicates where a link is directed.

\n

The Destination Page is the actual URL to which the Anchor Text is linking.

\n

An example of this would be, “For more information, check out our Product Page.” The Anchor Text is “check out our Product Page” and the Destination Page would be the Product Page. By clearly defining where this page link is directed, search engines and users will have an easier time navigating your site.

\n

\n

Image Descriptions & Alt Text

\n

All images should be embedded with descriptions of what the image is depicting. Most CMS platforms will have a simple feature that allows you to do this without any coding, but for those of you doing the hard coding by yourself, be sure that any <image> tags also include an "Alt" attribute like this:

\n

<img src="images/empire_state_building.jpg" alt="View of Manhattan and the Empire State Building"/>

\n

Search engines can't actually "see" the image, they only know it's there because of what the HTML code is telling it. The "Alt" text tells search engines what your images are showing and how they will be relevant to readers.

\n

Remember, Google is looking for quality, reliable information. So any attempts to “game” the system, or overload your site with keywords and links will be met with severe penalties to your SEO performance. Just follow these simple steps and watch your SEO rankings improve.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n

\n

\nIntegrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n\n
\n

Web Governance

\n

Websites have become so large and complex that being concerned with the strategies, goals and standards you have for your website is an entire career. Here at Siteimprove for example, we have separate advisors and tools for handling servers, search engines solutions, web analysis, web accessibility and SEO. Large websites and portals are an integration of many different systems that often come from different parties. Handling and controlling the website therefore becomes a complex unit to work with and there are too many cooks in the kitchen.

\n

We have a series of blog posts on web governance and how to implement it. This blog post will focus on how to best integrate your goals for web accessibility into your web governance strategy.

\n

Online self-service is by far the most affordable way to service your users/customers. Contact by phone or in person requires dedicated staff time, and detracts from your other initiatives. The importance of accessibility is that it helps ensure as many users as possible can use your website. Being accessible to 90% of users rather than being accessible to 70% of users can make a big difference on your bottom line.

\n

Accessibility

\n

Accessibility is often a neglected part of making a website strategy. The project manager usually has too much on their plate, and accessibility slips through the cracks.  It isn't neglected as a result of not caring or a lack of interest, but rather because there is too much trust put in the vendors. The tendency is to assume that they know what to do, and that adding accessibility to your requirements specification means it will be taken care of. Unfortunately, this is far from the case.

\n

Another problem is that many web managers do not know enough about accessibility to know that ensuring good web accessibility is a process, rather than just a coding task during development.

\n

I have been involved in many web projects where an executive in the organizations says: "Our website must meet WCAG, the web accessibility guidelines on all conformance levels," but they have no idea what this entails. Accessibility isn't something that can be simply added into the current web project and the new website budget. For example, if you want to add a video to your website and want it conform to the guidelines on level AA (which is mandatory for many public websites) it requires a number of things for video content. You must provide captions, audio description and a number of other things. If you wish to conform on level AAA you must also provide sign language of the content. Do you have the resources for this every time you upload a video to the website?

\n

Accessibility is relevant as an on-going process during the lifetime of the website. Every time you integrate a third party solution or you upload video or audio content and similar situations. The publishing process of web editors and the CMS that the website is based on also has influence on the ability and the situation of whether the publishing praxis supports accessibility or whether it introduces new accessibility issues.

\n

It's a good idea to have a separate strategy for ambitions on accessibility and what strategy to have in order to ensure it. It is also important to integrate the number of accessibility criteria relevant in the organization's communications policy, design guide, policy for purchase and the likes. Create a matrix of the stakeholders in the process.

\n

Helpful Tips

\n

It's also a good idea to divide it into a set of areas of responsibility and subsidiary goals:

\n
    \n
  • Who will ensure that the right requirements are made at the right time with the vendors?
    • \n
  • Who will ensure that accessibility is integrated in the different policies for the organization? (Communications policy, design guide, policy for purchase and the likes).
    • \n
  • Who takes responsibilities for accessibility during design and development?
    • \n
  • How do we ensure that the requirements are met? Remember the CMS, video and audio players, forms and all the technical tools that are connected to and integrated with the website.
    • \n
  • Who ensures that web editors and authors of documents are trained to have an accessible publishing praxis?
    • \n
  • Who ensures that there is an on-going process of checking if the guidelines are met and that no new accessibility issues are introduced on the website?
    • \n
\n

It's important to have established the division of ownership and responsibilities on all the different areas, and you should have an accessibility coordinator. This person is consulted when new decisions are made for the website. This could be re-structuring, new purchases and integration, change of existing policies and the likes. And this person has a written network of contacts inside and outside the organization. People that in some way can affect the website and its content.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792136864:\n\n\n\n\n\n5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n\n

    • \n

    • \n

    • \n

\n

\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n5 Ways to Determine Your Website's ROI\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/21/14 9:14 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Measuring the ROI of a website is incredibly important. At any time, you may be called upon to prove that the company's website is worth the investment, or even to defend your budget - and that could mean defending your salary, too. The ROI of a website isn't always as simple as presenting "expenses going out" and "profit coming in." Sometimes you may find yourself explaining your website's ROI to individuals who don't even know how to use the web let alone understand its value as a marketing tool. Before you can appropriately measure a website's ROI, upper management needs to have specific marketing, administrative and client service goals for the site in mind. Once you know exactly which metrics the website is being judged on, you can begin calculating the website's return.

\n
\n
\n

\n

1. Use lead generation forms for additional value

\n

Providing leads is a tangible benefit that a site can provide, and can be translated directly into a quantifiable ROI. Even better, it's the type of benefit that marketers will always understand. The more leads your website can generate, the better its ROI will be on average. To improve your lead generation you should use lead generation forms throughout your website to encourage users to sign up for newsletters and alerts, or to connect through social media. Giveaways and sweepstakes are another excellent way to acquire leads; everyone loves a freebie. Once you've acquired these leads, you can begin the task of valuing them based on conversion rates.

\n

2. Calculate a net promoter score for sites without direct revenue streams

\n

Calculating the ROI for an e-commerce website is a relatively simple process: you simply deduct your expenses from income and you have your return. For websites that don't sell anything, such as informational sites or government sites, a net promoter score is often useful. A net promoter score separates your visitors or customers into three categories: those that adore you, those that could take or leave you and those that are actively working against you. You will need to be prepared to show the value of this net promoter score, such as by showing how positivity within your customers translates into increased sales for the company.

\n

3. Measure money saved through self-service portions of the website

\n

A website can lower overall administrative costs by streamlining regular customer tasks, such as by reducing troubleshooting time through comprehensive documentation or simply connecting clients to the employees most likely to help them. Not only does this save a company significant amounts of money, but it also increases overall customer satisfaction. The value of a website can be further proven through the use of exit surveys that ask the customer how satisfied they were with the self-service process, how likely they would have been to contact the company directly otherwise and whether their interaction with the website will encourage purchases in the future.

\n

4. Capture all possible analytics regarding the website's use

\n

It's simply not possible to determine your website's return on investment unless you're tracking analytic data from end-to-end. This is especially true of non-marketplace websites. You need to be able to determine which parts of the site are being accessed, how often and for how long. Additionally, you should be able to tell where the traffic is coming from, where it is going and how many visitors are actually being converted into sales or leads. If your website does not have sales or leads, you might instead capture analytics regarding readership.

\n

5. Identify the administrative benefits for employers and supervisors

\n

Many companies undervalue the ROI of their websites because they don't consider the hidden benefits it offers for both employees and management. There are many websites that operate as employee portals, facilitating communication, document sharing and project collaboration; these are quantifiable benefits that are nevertheless often neglected when calculating ROI because they don't deal directly with the consumer.

\n

Only websites that are stable, accessible and well-designed will be able to develop a consistent return. Siteimprove offers website quality assurance, accessibility, analytics and alert services to ensure that your website functions as it should and provides the greatest possible value to your company. Even better, Siteimprove is an automated system that won't waste your company's website budget on administrative tasks.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics: Web Analytics, Web Governance

\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Eight Deadly Web Analytic Sins

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n8/27/13 3:20 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With budgets continuing to tighten, and workloads increasing, analytics has become a must-have in every professional marketer’s toolbox. However, for many it is still difficult to distinguish between reliable data and valid data. The difference is essentially the way in which the analytics data is set up and subsequently interpreted. In the following eight points we will show how you can end up with data that looks reliable but that is unfortunately not valid by committing a few simple sins.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

\n

Get inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you ready to manage smart-phone access on your website?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/25/12 5:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

By taking a quick glance at mobile web statistics, we can see an obvious increase in mobile phone users. Every indication points to this trend only continuing to grow. According to an analysis by Morgan Stanley, it is estimated that the number of Internet users who access the Internet through mobile units will exceed the number of users who access the Internet from traditional computers in 2014. The analysis is from 2010 and whether the results will prove true in 2014 is hard to say, but larger and better screens on smart phones, more powerful processors and flat-rate data subscriptions have an influence on the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

User Feedback - Building a closer relationship with your users

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n6/27/12 10:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Communicating with your users online often comes in the form of one way communication. This makes it hard for you to gain insight into what users actually think about your website. In this blog details how user feedback helps build a closer relationship with users, based on a case study of a municipal website in Denmark the Siteimprove has carried out since December 2011.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nGet inspiration from your analytics data when planning a new website \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n9/19/12 4:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you re-designing or having a new website? Get a good start by getting inspiration from your analytics data. Besides thinking about SEO and Accessibility, as our last two posts were about, it’s also a good idea to consider web analytics when you have to develop a new website or make a major redesign of your existing one.

\n
\n\n
\n

There is a wide variety of opportunities to use web analytics to help you create your new website. It can be anything from documenting your results to make your case for management to allocate the resources needed, to analysis that supports the graphical design and target group analysis that can be used to develop user profiles of the visitors.

\n

But basically there are two phases when we talk about web analytics in connection with the re-design and development of new website: a pre-launch phase and a post-launch phase.

\n

Phase 1: Pre-Launch

\n

The pre-launch phase is where web analytics should be implemented in the project as early as possible to give you strategic advantages by having access to information about how visitors use your existing website.

\n

By using web analytics to understand how visitors use your existing website when you're doing your initial research for your new website, you ensure that you right from the start is supporting the redesign or new web project with relevant data.

\n

Specifically, it can provide answers to essential questions that anyone who has a website should know. Questions like:

\n
    \n
  • Who are our users?
    • \n
  • What content on our current website do they look at?
    • \n
  • How do they end up on our current website?
    • \n
  • What do they do/where do they go when they visit the website?
    • \n
  • What feedback have we received from our users?
    • \n
\n

Knowing the geographic location of your users, their technical specifications, and whether they use computers or mobile devices when visiting your website will give you a clearer picture of your users and where to focus your efforts. It isn't realistic to expect to have complete answers for all the questions above, but combined with other information such as a survey the picture of the users' profiles is much sharper.

\n

Combine the above with an analysis of the most popular content (and the least popular), how users are finding the website, the users' behavior and the most used routes on the website, and you have a strong foundation to support and develop the web strategy for its re-design/new website.

\n

Phase 2: Post-Launch

\n

After the launch of your new website/redesign, you must ensure the continuous optimization of your website by implementing a lasting workflow enabling the constant measuring, analyzing and optimizing of your website. This process must be an iterative process where you are constantly working to optimize the user experience for your visitors.

\n

In order to work iteratively to optimize and analyze your new website, you need to have access to the correct Key Performance Indicators (KPI's), measurements, and a full dataset available. This brings us back to the pre-launch phase again.

\n

During the planning and development in the pre-launch phase you should ensure you have implemented your web analytics tool properly. At the same time, it's important to make sure you have developed your website in a way that makes it possible to extract the data needed to work with the continuous optimization of the website. A proper set-up from the start does not cost that much extra time, but will certainly pay off in the long run.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

    • \n

    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792143104:\n\n\n\n\n\nGoing for gold; developing an elite website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nGoing for gold; developing an elite website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n\n
\n

In this blog post I've collected a few standout posts from the last six months to give you an overview of some of the disciplines you can "train" your website in to keep it competitive.

\n

Quality assurance & accessibility

\n

The first step in the battle for a gold medal is to make sure your website is free from injury. We haven't really blogged about the importance of keeping your website free from spelling mistakes and broken links, but this is an obvious first hurdle. If your website is free from broken links and spelling mistakes it's then easier for users to understand and use your content.

\n

Besides correcting spelling mistakes and broken links, it is important to make sure that your website is accessible to everybody (if you are going for the big win). Your website should be useable for users who are limited by a handicap or technology, but also for search engines. You can read more about these topics in the following blog posts:

\n
    \n
  • 3 ways to improve your accessibility right now
    • \n
  • Lend the Search Engines a helping hand
    • \n
\n

Goals, measurement and optimization

\n

In the same way as the professional athletes are constantly measuring their performance and studying videos of themselves to improve, it is important that you continuously measure the performance of your website. This will allow you to identify where there is room for improvement.

\n

Before you start measuring and optimizing, it is important that you set achievable goals for your website, and know what your level of ambition is. No athlete in their right mind dreams of winning an Olympic gold medal in the 100 meter sprint, if they only practice once a week. Setting realistic but ambitious goals that are in line with the available resources is a strategic exercise, which should be orchestrated by management.

\n

Putting the strategy to work by measuring and optimizing your website is what you can read about in these blog posts:

\n
    \n
  • Dive into search statistics
    • \n
  • Expand your analysis with an extra dimension
    • \n
  • On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website
    • \n
  • Create an annual search cycle
    • \n
\n

The posts I've included here cover just some of the things you can do to keep your website fit. You can get even more ideas from the other posts in our blog archive, but the most important thing is that you are aware that a website (like an Olympian) demands constant attention and improvement to be on top of the game.

\n

If you have any ideas on how to keep a website fit, or any requests for topics you'd like to see covered in future blog posts then please fire away in the comments.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792147554:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nThe Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content \n

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\n
\n

The same philosophy can serve as a model for creating new content or assessing existing content. Content that successfully meets the higher-level, strategic needs of the audience and the business also needs to succeed on the lower levels shown above. Each level in this hierarchy will probably have different degrees of priority depending on whether the content is a blog post, a video, news release, etc.

\n

Following Maslow’s lead, the description of this pyramid starts at the ground level and works up from there. It’s worth noting that these are building blocks, and NOT intended to represent a linear process. You need to consider each of these levels before, during, and after you create content (or as you assess existing content).

\n

1. Accurate

\n

This is the foundational baseline, the food/water/shelter level for content.

\n
    \n
  • Is it factually accurate?
    • \n
  • Is it grammatically correct and free of typos?
    • \n
  • Has it been entered into the CMS correctly?
    • \n
  • Do the links work?
    • \n
  • Does it have metadata?
    • \n
\n

The good news is that there are tools that can help with this. Many content management systems include spell-check tools, and there are also external tools (such as Siteimprove) that do this. In fact, the benefit of using tools for these foundational elements is that the people involved in creating and managing the content can focus on the remaining aspects of the content hierarchy.

\n

2. Necessary

\n

This addresses whether the content needs to exist at all.

\n
    \n
  • Is this content unique on the site? Unique on the Web?
    • \n
  • Is it topical and timely?
    • \n
  • Is it relevant to the audience?
    • \n
  • Is it appropriate for the business to share?
    • \n
  • Is it required for the audience to know?
    • \n
\n

3. Authentic

\n

This addresses whether the content is (and should be) from our organization. For some organizations, this will consist only of original information; for others, their content will include analysis of others’ information (known as “curation”).

\n
    \n
  • If it is original content, is it created in our brand voice?
    • \n
  • If it is curated content, is the original source attributed and our analysis clearly identified?
    • \n
  • If it contains an executive byline, was it actually written by that person?
    • \n
  • Are we providing the context/analysis/perspective that only we can offer and that will help our audience use the information?
    • \n
\n

4. Effective

\n

This is about promotion and measurement.

\n
    \n
  • Does the audience know that this content exists?
    • \n
  • Do other internal content creators know about it?
    • \n
  • What is the size of the target audience?
    • \n
  • Do we have a goal and a call-to-action for this content?
    • \n
  • Do we have a plan for achieving that goal? (Editorial calendar for promotions on our site, on social media, in our e-newsletters, etc.)
    • \n
  • Will we measure how many people have seen/heard/used this content? Will we know who they are?
    • \n
\n

5. Strategic

\n

This is the pinnacle of the consideration pyramid. It addresses why the organization is creating and publishing this content now.

\n
    \n
  • What business goals does this content help achieve?
    • \n
  • What user needs does this content meet?
    • \n
  • Does it have a lifecycle for reviewing/renewing/expiring it?
    • \n
  • What do we expect this content to help us accomplish?
    • \n
\n

Organizations, make a decision to publish content or keep it online only when it works on all five of these levels. Content that works at the highest level is truly ready to succeed.

\n

Bio:

\n

Hilary Marsh is chief strategist and principal at Content Company, a Chicago-based content strategy consultancy. Thanks to @ContentScotland, @Content1st, @robram, @MxDEJ, and @GetSprkd for their input.

\n

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792147964:\n\n\n\n\n\nPutting a Face on Accessibility\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
