\n

\nPutting a Face on Accessibility\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/29/13 10:25 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

All too often we forget to put a face on people with disabilities, instead we lump them into categories.

\n
\n\n
\n

I’d like to introduce you to my friend Keith:

\n

Keith is a father and grandfather, a minister, and has been counseling troubled youth for over 30 years. He’s a diehard sports fan and spends his nights and weekends announcing games for the local college’s football, volleyball, basketball, and baseball teams.

\n

As a self-described technology buff, you’ll never find Keith without his iPhone. He loves taking pictures, especially of his new grandson. If you were to add Keith on Facebook, you could practically watch the boy grow up in his news feed. 

\n

Few people are as well traveled as Keith, who’s forever on a mission to become “mayor of everywhere” on Foursquare. Accompanying him on his adventures is his guide dog, a beautiful Black Labrador Retriever named Mercury.

\n

Keith is blind.

\n

Too often we forget to put a face on the people with disabilities. We lump them into categories:

\n
    \n
  • Blindness or Low Vision
    • \n
  • Deaf/Hard-of-Hearing
    • \n
  • Learning Disabilities
    • \n
  • Medical Disabilities
    • \n
  • Physical Disabilities
    • \n
\n

While these categories are conditions, they do not describe the individuals. They certainly do not describe Keith.

\n

Accessibility is something that is relevant for everyone working with websites regardless of whether you are a web designer, web developer, web manager, or web editor. As website specialists, we like to think we are pretty good at defining our audiences. Did you know that 20% of your users have some form of disability? One person out of five visiting your site has to do something out of the ordinary to get the information you’ve made available. Let’s look at this a different way—for every 1000 visitors, 200 may have difficulty with your site, or need an alternative way to get to your information. Alternative ways may include screen readers or screen magnifiers, braille readers, or keyboard only navigation.

\n

When you and your team redesigned your site the last time, did your UX designer include people with disabilities in the personas used for the site’s redesign? If you are not familiar with a persona, here is a brief description from Wikipedia:

\n

“In marketing and user-centered design, personas are fictional characters created to represent the different user types within a targeted demographic, attitude and/or behavior set that might use a site, brand or product in a similar way.”

\n

Personas are just one tool that can help with creating websites; to be effective your personas need to accurately reflect your visitors. If possible, engage a person with a disability to assist with persona creation, then re-engage your expert when it’s time to start testing the changes you’ve made to your site. For more information about creating accessible websites, read our blog posts “Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites”, “Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website”, and The Web Designer's Guide on How to Create Accessible GUIs.

\n

When you meet Keith, (or Bill, Sarah, or any other disabled person) for the first time, be sure to ask how much the grandson is growing, how their favorite sports team is doing, or about their latest hobby. If it’s Keith, be prepared to stop and chat for a while. He’s got some pictures to show you!

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\nTake a Load Off: Reduce Your Workload Through Website Automation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

We’ve all been there: deadlines are looming and there just aren’t enough hours in the day to meet them all. Website management teams are often too busy putting out fires and treading water to look for smarter ways to work, so we’ve taken it upon ourselves to do the research for you. Here are 4 great ways that you can save yourself time on things you already do.

\n\n

Assistant Apps

\n

Time consuming tasks like managing new assets and doing data entry can quickly derail your workday. Luckily, there are several web and mobile based apps which allow you to automate these jobs and free you to focus on your other work. While a number of great solutions exist, we suggest trying a variety to find the best option for your business. Here are a few of our favorites that have mass appeal:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    IFTTT (If This, Then That): Is an easy to use, logic based trigger app for iPhone and Android. It allows you to create “recipes” in order to combine the functionality of your favorite apps and services. For example, IF a new photo is posted to my Instagram account “JDoe”, THEN upload that photo to my “JDoe” folder in Dropbox. Just create the recipe and IFTTT will take care of the rest.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Zapier: This innovative tool allows you to leverage the benefits of multiple services and save time on data entry, inbound marketing, even social media postings. Say you’ve set up a new landing page with a form to capture data. With Zapier, you can combine your CMS (like Wordpress) with Google Docs to automatically send captured data directly to a formatted spreadsheet, saving you time and preventing carpal tunnel syndrome.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Quality Assurance & Reporting

\n

As your site grows, keeping track of every link, PDF, and piece of unique content becomes more difficult. Over time, these materials will be updated, moved, or deleted, but it can be easily overlooked without an automated tool like these:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Xenu: This free tool may be slightly dated, but if you’re only looking to find your website’s broken links, this will do the trick. The user experience isn’t very polished or intuitive, but you get what you pay for.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: We’ve heard great things about this tool, and apparently the employees are all amazing people. With our web governance suite, we’ll scan your site for broken links and misspellings, then provide a detailed report showing you exactly where the errors occur. It even works with PDFs.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Checking for Consistent Content

\n

Beyond the issues caused by broken links and misspellings, dated and poor quality content will also turn off potential customers. If your business has updated its branding, changed service descriptions, or needs to add legally required material to its site, you need a reliable system for ensuring that the new content is in place, but also that the old material has been completely removed. We’ve got you covered:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: Our new Content Policy tool allows users to automatically identify specific words and phrases in order to ensure that your content is accurate and present on the required pages. This can help with branding consistency, content strategy, and legally required disclaimers.

    \n
    • \n
\n

SEO Analysis

\n

You’ve spent valuable time and resources on creating your site’s content, but if you’re not making it easy for people and search engines to find, it will all be for nothing. Analyzing your site’s search engine optimization (SEO) performance will help you determine if you’re reaching your audience successfully. Here are some options:

\n
    \n
  • \n

    Google Analytics: Yes, everyone knows about Google Analytics, mostly because you can get some pretty robust features for free. The downside is that you need to know a thing or ten about SEO and website analytics to use it effectively. That, and Google gets unrestricted access to all of the information it mines…hey, you agreed to the Terms of Service.

    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    Siteimprove: Our SEO tool allows you to monitor the performance of your website content with the comfort of knowing that your information will always be safe. You’ll also have access to training and support from our dedicated team should you ever have questions or need a little help.

    \n
    • \n
\n

Using the right tools for the job is how things get done right the first time. Take some pressure off of your website management team and let website automation do the dirty work.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility and Our Aging Population

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n6/17/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

How many of you have heard the term “Silver surfer”? A Silver surfer is an individual over the age of 50 who utilizes the Internet on a consistent basis. In this month’s post, we’re going to address the issue of website accessibility and our aging population.

\n

As mentioned in previous posts, approximately 20% of our population is living with some form of disability of varying severity, and thanks to medical and technological advances, that statistic is on the rise due to our aging population.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Roles & Responsibilities on Website Teams

\n

\nPosted by\nShane Diffily\n

\n

\n6/3/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

People are the most important part of any system of Web Governance. Hire good people and they will generally find clever and innovative ways to get maximum bang for your buck. However, roles & responsibilities have not kept pace with changes in online activity. This has led to dangerous gaps in operations, as well as tension among staff due to competing claims over “who does what”.

\n

In this article we’ll explore some of the ways you can restore 'industrial peace' by delivering the clear job descriptions your team needs.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

The Cost of Your Website's Broken Links

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

It may not seem like much on the surface, but deep down, a broken link is doing some serious damage to your website, your reputation, and your business. A single broken link can impact your search engine rankings, your site’s user experience, result in lost customers and revenue, or everyone’s favorite- all of the above.

\n
\nRead More\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n

    \n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day: Gain a New Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/15/14 9:09 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Close your eyes. Now try to read the rest of this paragraph. You didn’t make it very far did you? Imagine how difficult it would be to navigate a website or read a spreadsheet without the aid of assistive technology and website accessibility.

\n

Global Accessibility Awareness Day is aimed at fostering discussions within the design, development, and usability communities as they continue to build, shape, and influence new assistive technologies. The goal is to raise the profile and increase awareness around the topic of digital accessibility, which includes web, mobile, and software experiences. To help spread the word, we're offering our two-part Accessibility Certification Course to everyone for FREE!

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Are You Coding Your Website Data Tables For Accessibility?

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n5/13/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

We can all agree that using an HTML table for page layout is wrong. For those of you who didn’t know that, thank you for sticking with me into sentence two, I promise this will all make sense if you keep reading. There are many appropriate uses for tables on websites, but the problem lies in understanding the proper way to make those tables accessible for all users. Don’t panic, tables are not to be feared or avoided! With some careful planning and a better understanding of the different table elements and attributes, you too can add usable data tables to your web pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

    \n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency?

\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n

How to Win Friends and Influence Your Web Team

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n2/5/14 8:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Stop me if you’ve heard this one: You’re the website manager, and you’re held responsible for the quality of your web content - but you have content contributors from other departments over whom you hold no real power. That means you’re held accountable for the quality of their work, but have no way to make them actually do it. If they decide not to fix issues that come up, it reflects poorly on you. Fortunately, there are ways to manage this situation! Since you don’t have administrative influence over these team members, you’ll have to rely on relational influence – which is better anyway.

\n
\nRead More\n

    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Issues with your website can be absolutely devastating. Despite any of the marketing momentum or client base that you've built up, you may find your traffic ranking and following drastically tanking due to website errors. Lag, bad links, a lack of accessibility and even outdated content can quickly damage a website's SEO and lose the faith of its readership. Luckily, there are some ways you can avoid these issues before they even become a problem.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n
\nRead More\n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.
